      U.S. UNVEILS PLAN TO IMPROVE SHARING OF DRUG-TRAFFICKING DATA
      By ISMAIL TURAY JR.
      c.2000 Cox News Service

   WASHINGTON _ The Clinton administration on Monday introduced a
plan for sharing information about drug trafficking that it says
will greatly help in the war on drugs.

   The General Counterdrug Intelligence Plan was unveiled by
representatives of eight federal agencies, including the CIA, the
Justice Department and the State Department.

   The $186 million program will build a data base of information
on seized drugs and improve the government's ability to provide
information to every facet of the law enforcement community, Gen.
Barry McCaffrey, head of the Office of National Drug Control
Policy, said at a news conference.

   The plan also aims to improve cooperation among federal, state
and local law enforcement agencies, and maps out ways to improve
the cooperation of U.S. and international partners in the fight
against drugs.

   ``I think we can do so much if we use the tools that have been
developed in this plan and use them wisely,'' said Attorney General
Janet Reno.

   ``The fight against narcotics is a top priority for American
intelligence, and the plan is a great move for Americans,'' said
deputy CIA director Gen. John Gordon. ``The entire (intelligence)
community is 100 percent behind this effort, and we will do our
very best'' to make sure that it succeeds.

   The plan is based on a study by a White House task force
commissioned in 1997. Seven cabinet departments and five federal
law enforcement agencies, as well as state and local law
enforcement organizations and the National Security Council, worked
to turn the task force's 89 recommendations into 73 separate
initiatives.

   Besides sharing drug intelligence and improving coordination
among different levels of U.S. and foreign governments, the
initiatives include personnel development, training, and
information technology.
